table-wrap.anchoringText: By May 2011 before the steam flooding study started, a total of 43 wells had been drilled, including one horizontal well; 36 wells have been put into operation, of which 23 wells are producing as cold, and 13 wells for steam stimulation; 33 wells were opened, with a daily oil production of 5722bbl, a daily fluid production of 6097bbl, a water cut of 6.1%, the total Orignial Oil In place (OOIP) is 298.7 MM STB, and the up to date recovery factor of reserves is 0.75%. The average daily production for steam stimulation is 2 to 3 times of the cold wells. see Table (1) and Figure (1) for FNE OOIP, Reserve and Cummulative Production.
table-wrap.label: Table 1
table-wrap.caption: OOIP & Reserve Status

table-wrap.anchoringText: Most of the previous resreach and studies confirm that FNE oil field is suitable for thermal enhanced oil recovery and the cyclic steam injection wells reward more than double production compare to cold wells, according to the common standards for heavy oil thermal recovery in Table (2), comparatively analyze the geological features of FNE Oilfield Table (1), and consider that FNE oilfield is suitable for heat mining development.
table-wrap.label: Table 2
table-wrap.caption: Screening Creataria for Thermal Recovery and Development

formatted-caption.caption-text: Screening Creataria for Thermal Recovery and Development

table-wrap.anchoringText: Most of the previous resreach and studies confirm that FNE oil field is suitable for thermal enhanced oil recovery and the cyclic steam injection wells reward more than double production compare to cold wells, according to the common standards for heavy oil thermal recovery in Table (2), comparatively analyze the geological features of FNE Oilfield Table (1), and consider that FNE oilfield is suitable for heat mining development.
table-wrap.label: Table 2
table-wrap.caption: Similar Reservoir Parameters Comparison (SPE-104403)

tr.th: Tectonic lithology with edge bottom water
Tectonic lithology with edge bottom water
Tectonic lithology with edge bottom water

table-wrap.anchoringText: Most wells in the selected pilot area are the steam stimulation wells, and the reservoir thickness is greater than 9m, For the completion data of 6 wells in the Pilot area, in addition to FNE-1 well which is cold, all are thermal recovery completions. The single well developed reservoir of the oil layer group composed by B1a, B1b, and B1c are greater than 9 m. All are for steam stimulation operation, with an average daily oil production of 341bbl/d-Table (3).
table-wrap.label: Table 3
table-wrap.caption: Production Data Statistics on Steam Stimulation Wells in the Pilot Area

formatted-caption.caption-text: Production Data Statistics on Steam Stimulation Wells in the Pilot Area

table-wrap.anchoringText: By analysis of the reserve, structure, connectivity, oil saturation and other parameters of FNE-35, FNE-36, FNE-37 and FNE-38 well micro-structure area, the area is in line with the selection principle for steam injection pilot test area. FNE-38 well micro-structure area is recommended as the area for Steam Flooding pilot test, the test area well no. FNE-7, 34, 35, 36, 37, and 38, a total of 6 wells and its main geological parameters in table (4) below
table-wrap.label: Table 4
table-wrap.caption: FNE Main Geological Parameters

tr.td: Degassing viscosity of crude oil at 50ï:
Geological reserves of selected well group

table-wrap.anchoringText: Compared with the fine geological model, the geological reserves have a gap of 5.18%; and the maximum relative errors of accumulative fluid, oil and water productions, steam injection amount is less than 10%, in line with the industry standard for numerical simulation, See Table (5) and Figures (7 and 8) for whole model and typical single well such as FNE-37 the production history matching is very good.
table-wrap.label: Table 5
table-wrap.caption: History Matching Results

table-wrap.anchoringText: From table (5a) it’s clearly that case 5 and 6 is most likely to be the opmimum cases, and in order to select the best case adetail design has been conduct for each case include the following
table-wrap.label: Table 5a
table-wrap.caption: Numerical Model Results Comparison of Parameters at Different Cases

formatted-caption.caption-text: Numerical Model Results Comparison of Parameters at Different Cases

table-wrap.anchoringText: Numerical simulation results for turning to Steam Flooding after Case5 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 and 6 cycles are as shown in Table (6). Compared with profits and recovery percent of reserves, switching to Steam Flooding after the second period of steam stimulation is the best.
table-wrap.label: Table 6
table-wrap.caption: Case 5 Comparison of Steam Flooding Production Results at Different Cycles

formatted-caption.caption-text: Case 5 Comparison of Steam Flooding Production Results at Different Cycles

table-wrap.anchoringText: Numerical simulation results for turning to Steam Flooding after Case6 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 and 6 cycles are as shown in Table (7), Compared recovery percent of reserves, switching to Steam Flooding after the second period of steam stimulation is also the best.
table-wrap.label: Table 7
table-wrap.caption: Case 6 Comparison of Steam Flooding Production Results at Different Cycles

formatted-caption.caption-text: Case 6 Comparison of Steam Flooding Production Results at Different Cycles

table-wrap.anchoringText: Taking Case5 as an example, under the conditions that the Steam Flooding parameters are as follows: the steam injection temperature of 270°C, the steam injection pressure of 5 ~ 7MPa, steam injection quality of 0.6, and the recovery ratio of over 1.2, with the design steam injection rate at 1.2, 1.4, 1.6, 1.8, and 2 m3/d/ha/m, make a contrast on the recovery percent of reserves. See Table (8) and figure (18).
table-wrap.label: Table 8
table-wrap.caption: Case 5 Comparison of Steam Flooding Production Results at Different Rates

formatted-caption.caption-text: Case 5 Comparison of Steam Flooding Production Results at Different Rates

table-wrap.anchoringText: Taking Case5 as an example, under the conditions of the steam injection temperature of 270°C, the steam injection pressure of 5 ~ 7MPa, steam injection quality of 0.6, and the steam injection rate of 1.6m3/d/ha/m, with the design injection-production ratio at 0.8, 1.0, 1.2, 1.4 and 1.6, make a contrast on the recovery percent of reserves, See Table (9) and Figure (19) for the oil-steam ratio. It is recommended to use the injection-production ratio of 1.2.
table-wrap.label: Table 9
table-wrap.caption: Case 6 comparison table of Steam Flooding Production Results at Different Injection-Production Ratios

formatted-caption.caption-text: Case 6 comparison table of Steam Flooding Production Results at Different Injection-Production Ratios

table-wrap.anchoringText: From tables (8, 9 and 10) The results showed that converting of Cyclic Steam Stimulation (CSS) to steam flooding after the third cycle could improve the recovery factor of the field up to 43 ~ 50.1%, while CSS only can increase the recovery percent of the suggested well groups by 32.5 - 34.2% of the studied sector model which makes it more attractive method as development scenario for FNE oil field.
table-wrap.label: Table 10
table-wrap.caption: Case 6 Development Indicator Prediction
